item.title: UniCredit, Italy’s Largest Bank, Posts Surprisingly Big Loss
item.description: The lender says its holdings are far less valuable than thought, as the European Central Bank plans to scrutinize the books of euro zone banks.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: UniCredit's headquarters in Milan. The bank reported a fourth-quarter loss of 15 billion euros, or about $21 billion.

item.title: The Lede: U.N. Denies Altering Image of Palestinian Refugees in Damascus
item.description: A United Nations spokesman rejected claims that an arresting image of thousands of Palestinian refugees waiting for food distribution on a ruined street in Damascus recently had been digitally altered.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A photograph of food distribution in a Damascus refugee camp for Palestinians released by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency in January.

item.title: Western Journalist Is Killed in Afghanistan
item.description: The attack on a reporter with dual British-Swedish nationality marked the first time in years that a foreigner appeared to have been specifically targeted and killed in Kabul.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Israeli Strike Kills 3 Palestinian Militants in Gaza
item.description: The airstrike and the unrelated crash of an Israeli surveillance drone came amid an increase in cross-border violence that has threatened a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Terror Links to Stolen Passports Discounted in Malaysia Jet Inquiry
item.description: Interpol said that two passengers known to have used stolen passports to board the Malaysia Airlines jet that vanished were unlikely to be linked to terrorist groups.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The authorities released photographs of two Iranians who boarded the Malaysia Airlines flight with false documents: Pouria Nourmohammadi Mehrdad, left, and another man, identified by Interpol as Delavar Seyed Mohammad Reza.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 11
item.description: A woman at an election rally in Balasinor, Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Malaysia Jet Changed Course at Time of Disappearance, Officials Say
item.description: Malaysian officials said the jetliner may have radically altered its path around the time communications ended with ground controllers, possibly explaining the expansion of the search area.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Hoang Dinh Nam/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Malaysian authorities expanded the search area in recent days.

item.title: N.S.A. Nominee Warns Cyberthreats Will Only Increase
item.description: Citing cyberattacks on the new Ukraine government, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, Vice Admiral Michael S. Rogers, said “cyber will be an element of every crisis.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, right, was cautious in what he said in a hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday.

item.title: India Ink: Maoist Guerrillas Ambush Police in Chhattisgarh
item.description: An estimated 100 insurgents attacked police officers who were clearing a road for a construction crew in central India, a state police spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Safety Flaws Found in New Inspections of Factories in Bangladesh
item.description: Teams plan to assess 1,500 garment factories by early September; reports on the first 10 factories were released on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The April 2013 collapse of a textile factory outside Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: North Korea Skillfully Evades Sanctions, U.N. Panel Says
item.description: Recent seizures of banned cargo show that Pyongyang has used increasingly deceptive techniques, the panel’s report to the Security Council says.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ukraine’s Ousted Leader Urges Military to Resist New Government
item.description: Declaring that he remained commander in chief, Viktor F. Yanukovych denounced the West for rushing to recognize the interim authorities and to provide financial assistance.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Former Ukrainian president Viktor F. Yanukovych spoke at a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: Frustration Over Malaysian Flight Turns to Anger
item.description: Insults and water bottles were thrown at Malaysia Airlines staff members in Beijing over the lack of information about what has happened to Flight MH370.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Relatives of passengers waited for news at the Lido Hotel in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: China Details Plans to Liberalize Interest Rates and Encourage Private Banks
item.description: Analysts welcomed the announcements, which signaled progress in a far-ranging plan of overhauls designed to modernize the country’s financial system.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Satellites Redeployed to Search for Malaysia Airlines Plane
item.description: As China waits for news of the missing Malaysia Airlines flight, most of whose passengers were Chinese, its military said it had redeployed 10 satellites to aid the search.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Azharuddin Abdul Rahman, left, director general of Malaysia's Department of Civil Aviation, pointing to a chart of the search area on Monday with Ahmad Jauhari Yahya, the Malaysia Airlines chief executive.

item.title: India Ink: In Delhi, Hopeful Patients Turn to a Razor Blade for Treatment
item.description: New Delhi is full of world-class hospitals, but for some chronic sufferers, only the ancient medical practice of bloodletting will ease their pain.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Cmdr. William Marks of the U.S. Navy 7th Fleet on the Search for the Malaysian Jet
item.description: Cmdr. William Marks, the spokesman for the United States Navy Seventh Fleet, calls the search effort a “challenging puzzle” that is getting more complicated as every hour passes.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A SH-60R Seahawk helicopter taking off from the destroyer Pinckney, one of dozens of ships in the Gulf of Thailand searching for a sign of the missing Malaysia Airlines plane.

item.title: India Ink: ‘Cleanest Village’ Questions Its Blessings Amid Influx of Visitors
item.description: Mawlynnong, a village in the northeastern state of Meghalaya, struggles to maintain its reputation as a pristine ecotourism destination against an onslaught of tourists.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Children in Mawlynnong, India, working to clean the village, where a reputation for tidiness has brought tourists who aren't always cooperative.

item.title: Q. and A. on the Disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370
item.description: Matthew L. Wald, who has written about aviation for The New York Times, answers questions about plane crashes and what could have happened to the missing flight.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: A Vietnamese military helicopter on Monday flew over the Gulf of Thailand. Planes and copters from nine nations are scouring the waters near a Malaysia Airlines flight’s last reported location.

item.title: False Leads Set Back Search for Malaysian Jet
item.description: Authorities widen the search area after suspected debris and an oil slick turn out to be unconnected to a Malaysia Airlines flight that vanished Saturday night.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER, KEITH BRADSHER and MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: A member of the military looked out of a helicopter during a search-and-rescue mission off the Tho Chu Islands of Vietnam on Monday.

item.title: For Hateful Comic in France, Muzzle Becomes a Megaphone
item.description: Despite dozens of charges, French officials have been confounded in efforts to stop the performances of Dieudonné M’bala M’bala, who is seen as anti-Semitic.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Corentin Fohlen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dieudonné M’bala M’bala has been charged with anti-hate law violations 38 times in recent years.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkish Court Orders Release of 19 More in Plot Case
item.description: The men were convicted with scores of others of plotting a coup in the Ergenekon case, which the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan used to break the political power of Turkey’s military.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing: India’s Supreme Court Orders Speedier Trials for Lawmakers
item.description: India’s Supreme Court on Monday ordered lower courts to conclude the trials of lawmakers charged with grave crimes within a year of the date of the charges being filed as a way to reduce the number of politicians who are re-elected during drawn-out trials.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: World Briefing: Thieves in Gaza Go Where Money Is, but Hamas Quickly Gets It Back
item.description: Masked gunmen robbed a post office in Gaza City on Monday, stealing what local news reports said was the equivalent of about $500,000.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: U.S. and Russia Hit Diplomatic Roadblock Trying to Start Ukraine Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry delayed an anticipated trip to Russia and the two sides issued dueling accounts of their recent diplomacy to defuse the crisis in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and STEVEN LEE MYERS
